title: Two-stage switch for cordless hand-held ultrasonic cautery cutting device
abstract: An ultrasonic, self-powered surgical device includes a handle, a self-contained power supply associated with the handle, and a control circuit disposed within the handle and/or the power supply. The control circuit is operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device. A two-stage switch is electrically connected to the control circuit and effects the at least two operational conditions of the surgical device. A first stage of the switch effects a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effects a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition.
claims:
1. A self-powered surgical device, comprising:
a handle having:
a self-contained power supply; and a selectively removable energy generator module electrically coupled to the power supply and having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a two-stage switch electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition, the two-stage switch having a variable mechanical resistance such that:
the first stage occurs when a first depression force is applied to the switch;

the second stage occurs when a second depression force greater than the first depression force is applied to the switch; and a holding force lower than at least the second depression force is required to maintain the switch in the second stage.
2. The device according to claim 1, wherein the control circuit is operable to control the amount of power delivered from the power supply.

3. The device according to claim 2, wherein the first operational condition is a first amount of power delivered from the power supply and the second operational condition is a second amount of power delivered from the power supply.

4. The device according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch further comprises at least one electrical contact that is operable to electrically close the control circuit to affect the first and second of the at least two operational conditions.

5. The device according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch further comprises at least one electrical contact that is operable to electrically break the control circuit to affect the first and second of the at least two operational conditions.

6. The device according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch is operable to switch between the first and second stages by changing between a first position and a second position, whereby the switch is in the first position when the first depression force is applied and is in the second position when the second depression force is applied.
7. The device according to claim 6, wherein the two-stage switch is in the first stage when it is in the first position.
8. The device according to claim 7, wherein the two-stage switch is in the second stage when it is in the second position.
9. The device according to claim 8, wherein the first and second positions are operably connected in a stacked configuration.
10. The device according to claim 1, wherein the first depression force causes the switch to be partially depressed.
11. The device according to claim 10, wherein the second depression force causes the switch to be fully depressed.

12. The device according to claim 6, further comprising a plunger coupled to the two-stage switch and operable to change the positions of the two-stage switch when a pressure is applied to the plunger.
13. The device according to claim 12, wherein the plunger is spring-biased.
14. The device according to claim 12, wherein a variable amount of pressure is applied to the plunger to cause the two-stage switch to change position.

15. The device according to claim 12, wherein the amount of pressure needed to position the two-stage switch in the first stage is less than the amount of pressure needed to position the two-stage switch in the second stage.

16. The device according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch is comprised of at least a first sub-switch and a second sub-switch, the first sub-switch effecting the first stage and the second sub-switch effecting the second stage.

17. A surgical device, comprising:
a handle comprising a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a two-stage switch disposed on the handle and electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition, the two-stage switch having a variable mechanical resistance such that:
the first stage occurs when a first depression force is applied to the switch;

the second stage occurs when a second depression force greater than the first depression force is applied to the switch; and a holding force lower than at least the second depression force is required to maintain the switch in the second stage.

18. A surgical device, comprising:
a handle comprising a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a two-stage switch disposed on the handle and electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition, whereby the two-stage switch is operable to switch between first and second positions, the two-stage switch having a variable mechanical resistance such that:
the switch is in the first position when a first depression force is applied to the switch;
the switch is in the second position when a second depression force is applied to the switch; and a holding force lower than at least the second depression force is required to maintain the switch in the second stage.

19. A surgical device, comprising:
a handle comprising a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a two-stage switch disposed on the handle and electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition, whereby the two-stage switch is operable to change between the first and second stage when a force is applied thereto, wherein the force required to cause the switch to enter the second stage is greater than the force required to maintain the switch in the second stage.

20. A surgical device, comprising:
a handle comprising a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a two-stage switch disposed on the handle and electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition, whereby the two-stage switch is operable to switch between first and second positions when a force is applied thereto, wherein the force required to cause the switch to enter the second position is greater than the force required to maintain the switch in the second position.

22. The device according to claim 21, wherein the force required to cause the button to enter the first actuated position is less than a force required to cause the button to enter the second actuation position.

23. The device according to claim 21, wherein the force required to maintain the button in the first actuated position is less than a force required to cause the button to enter the second actuation position.

24. The device according to claim 21, wherein the force required to cause the button to enter the second actuated position is greater than the force required to maintain the button in the first actuated position.

25. The device according to claim 21, which further comprises a handle having a self-contained power supply, the energy generator module being disposed at the handle and operable to control power delivered from the power supply.
26. The device according to claim 25, wherein the first operational condition is power delivered from the power supply.
27. The device according to claim 25, wherein the second operational condition is power delivered from the power supply.

28. The device according to claim 21, wherein:
the button further comprises at least one electrical contact that electrically closes the control circuit to effect at least one of the at least two operational conditions.
29. The device according to claim 21, wherein the first actuated position is a partially depressed state of the button.
30. The device according to claim 29, wherein the second actuated position is a fully depressed state of the button.

31. The device according to claim 21, wherein the button comprises:
a two-position switch; and a plunger coupled to the two-position switch and operable to change the positions of the two-position switch when pressure is applied to the plunger.
32. The device according to claim 31, wherein the plunger is spring-biased.

33. The device according to claim 31, wherein the two-position switch is comprised of at least a first sub-switch and a second sub-switch, the first sub-switch effecting the first actuated position and the second sub-switch effecting the second actuated position.
34. The device according to claim 33, wherein the first and second sub-switches are operably connected in a stacked configuration.
35. The device according to claim 21, wherein a variable amount of pressure is applied to the button to cause the button to change between positions.

36. A surgical device control assembly, comprising:
a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a two-actuation-position button operatively connected to the control circuit and having a single actuation member, a first depressed position of the actuation member effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second depressed position of the actuation member in substantially the same direction effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition, wherein actuation of the two-actuation position button to the first depressed position and to the second depressed position is effected by application of a depression force thereto.

37. The device according to claim 36, wherein:
the depression force required to cause the single actuation member to enter the first depressed position is less than the depression force required to cause the single actuation member to enter the second depressed position; and the depression force required to maintain the single actuation member in the first depressed position is less than the depression force required to cause the single actuation member to enter the second depressed position.

38. The device according to claim 36, wherein the depression force required to cause the single actuation member to enter the second operational condition is greater than the force required to maintain the single actuation member in the first depressed position.

39. The device according to claim 36, wherein:
the first actuation position is a partially depressed state of the actuation member; and the second actuation position is a fully depressed state of the actuation member.

40. In a surgical device, a control assembly comprising:
a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a two-actuation-position button operatively connected to the control circuit and having a single actuation member, a first depressed position of the actuation member effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second depressed position of the actuation member in substantially the same direction effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition.
42. The assembly according to claim 41, wherein the energy delivering component does not deliver energy when the switch is in the unactuated position.

43. The assembly according to claim 41, wherein:
the actuation force required to cause the switch to enter the first actuated position is less than the actuation force required to cause the switch to enter the second actuated position; and the actuation force required to maintain the switch in the second actuated position being less than the force required to cause the switch to enter the second actuated position.
44. The assembly according to claim 41, wherein the actuation force is imparted by a user of the surgical device handle.

45. The assembly according to claim 41, the surgical device handle further comprising:
a control circuit electrically connected between the energy delivering component and the switch; and the switch further comprises at least one electrical contact that electrically closes the circuit.
46. The assembly according to claim 45, wherein the at least one electrical contact of the switch electrically closes the control circuit to activate the energy delivering component.
47. The assembly according to claim 46, wherein the first actuated position closes the control circuit to activate the energy delivering component.
48. The assembly according to claim 46, wherein the second actuated position closes the control circuit to activate the energy delivering component.
49. The assembly according to claim 41, wherein switching between the unactuated position and the first actuated position produces a user-audible sound.
50. The assembly according to claim 41, wherein switching between the first actuated position and the second actuated position produces a user-audible sound.
51. The assembly according to claim 41, wherein the energy delivering component delivers energy when the switch is in one of the first and second actuated positions.
52. The assembly according to claim 41, wherein the energy delivering component delivers energy when the switch is in both of the first and second actuated positions.
54. The assembly according to claim 53, wherein the energy delivering component does not deliver energy when the switch is in the rest position.

55. The assembly according to claim 53, wherein:
the press force required to cause the switch to enter the first position is less than the press force required to cause the switch to enter the second position; and the press force required to maintain the switch in the second position is less than the force required to cause the switch to enter the second position.
56. The assembly according to claim 53, wherein the energy delivering component delivers energy when the switch is in one of the first and second positions.
57. The assembly according to claim 53, wherein the energy delivering component delivers energy when the switch is in both of the first and second positions.
59. The assembly according to claim 58, wherein the energy delivering component delivers energy when the switch is in one of the first and second positions.
60. The assembly according to claim 58, wherein the energy delivering component delivers energy when the switch is in both of the first and second positions.

61. A method for operating a surgical device, comprising:
providing an energy generator module integrated with and selectively removable from a handle of the surgical device and having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and effecting the at least two operational conditions by actuating a two-stage switch to a first or second stage, the switch being electrically connected to the control circuit, the first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and the second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition, the two-stage switch having a variable mechanical resistance such that:
the first stage occurs when a first depression force is applied to the switch;
the second stage occurs when a second depression force greater than the first depression force is applied to the switch; and a holding force lower than at least the second depression force is required to maintain the switch in the second stage.

62. A method for operating a self-powered surgical device, comprising:
providing a handle with:
a self-contained power supply; and an energy generator module selectively removable from the handle and having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and effecting the at least two operational conditions by actuating a two-stage switch to a first stage or a second stage, the switch being electrically connected to the control circuit, the first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and the second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition, the two-stage switch having a variable mechanical resistance such that:
the first stage occurs when a first depression force is applied to the switch;

the second stage occurs when a second depression force greater than the first depression force is applied to the switch; and a holding force lower than at least the second depression force is required to maintain the switch in the second stage.

63. A method for operating a surgical device, comprising:
providing an energy generator module integrated with and selectively removable from a handle of the surgical device and having a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and effecting the at least two operational conditions by actuating a two-stage switch to a first stage or a second stage by applying an actuation force thereto, the switch being electrically connected to the control circuit, the first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and the second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition, wherein the actuation force required to cause the switch to enter the second stage is greater than the actuation force required to maintain the switch in the first stage.

64. In a surgical device comprising:
a handle with a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operative to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a button operatively connected to the control circuit, a method for operating the surgical device comprising:
actuating the button in a button-actuation direction from an unactuated rest point to a first actuated position at a first distance from the rest point in the button-actuation direction, the first actuated position effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions; and actuating the button in the button-actuation direction from the first actuated position to a second actuated position at a second distance further from the rest point in the button-actuation direction than the first distance, the second actuated position effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition.

65. In a surgical device comprising:
a handle with a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operative to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a button operatively connected to the control circuit, a method for operating the surgical device comprising:

pressing a single actuation member of the button to a first depressed position to thereby effect a first of the at least two operational conditions; and pressing the actuation member in substantially the same direction to a second depressed position to thereby effect a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition.

66. In a surgical device comprising:
a handle with a selectively removable energy generator module having a control circuit operative to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and a button operatively connected to the control circuit, a method for operating the surgical device comprising:
pressing a single actuation member of the button to a first depressed position thereby placing the button in a first actuated position to effect a first of the at least two operational conditions; and pressing the actuation member in substantially the same direction to a second depressed position thereby placing the button in a second actuated position to effect a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition.

title: Battery driven hand-held ultrasonic surgery cauterizing device
abstract: PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide a battery assembly for surgery device having a battery terminal and operation parameters.SOLUTION: A battery assembly 301 includes a housing of a shape removably connected to a battery terminal. The housing includes a module type battery, and the battery can be operated so as to supply power to a surgery device at the terminal. The housing includes a control circuit having a microprocessor, a memory 5706, and a real time clock. The control circuit is communicably connected to the battery, and can be operated so as to execute detection of identification information on the surgery device, to determine at least one piece of information on at least one of operation parameters for the surgery device based on the detected identification information, to store the information at least in the memory, and to make it possible or impossible selectively to supply power from the battery to the surgery device based on the information.SELECTED DRAWING: Figure 57

title: Cordless hand-held ultrasonic cautery cutting device
abstract: An ultrasonic surgical assembly includes an ultrasonic transducer operable to convert a received motional voltage into a movement of a cutting blade of an ultrasonic waveguide, a motional feedback circuit connected in a parallel configuration with the transducer, a variable power source operable to apply a first voltage between a set of connection points to the parallel configuration, a voltage meter operable to determine a feedback voltage measured from the motional feedback circuit, and a voltage controller operable to vary an output of the power source based upon the measured feedback voltage, resulting in a substantially constant feedback voltage and maintaining a substantially constant rate of movement of the cutting blade across a variety of cutting loads.
claims: 2. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 1, wherein the variable power source is connected in a parallel configuration with the series configuration of the ultrasonic transducer and the first capacitive element and with the series configuration of the second and third capacitive elements.

title: Method of Assembling a Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: A method for assembling an ultrasonic surgical device includes the steps of rotatably freely connecting an ultrasonic waveguide to an ultrasonic surgical handle body, the ultrasonic waveguide having a proximal coupling end, substantially simultaneously removably coupling an ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit to the ultrasonic surgical handle body and removably inserting an ultrasonic-movement-producing distal end of a cordless, rotatably free ultrasonic transducer into the ultrasonic surgical handle body opposite the proximal coupling end of the ultrasonic waveguide, and rotating the ultrasonic waveguide with respect to the ultrasonic transducer to fixedly couple the ultrasonic waveguide to the ultrasonic-movement-producing distal end of the ultrasonic transducer.
claims:
1. A method for assembling an ultrasonic surgical device, the method comprising:
rotatably freely connecting an ultrasonic waveguide to an ultrasonic surgical handle body, the ultrasonic waveguide having a proximal coupling end;
substantially simultaneously:
removably coupling an ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit to the ultrasonic surgical handle body; and
removably inserting an ultrasonic-movement-producing distal end of a rotatably free, cordless ultrasonic transducer into the ultrasonic surgical handle body opposite the proximal coupling end of the ultrasonic waveguide, the ultrasonic transducer being operable to dynamically produce a resonant wave along the ultrasonic waveguide when coupled thereto; and
rotating the ultrasonic waveguide with respect to the ultrasonic transducer to fixedly couple the ultrasonic waveguide to the ultrasonic-movement-producing distal end of the ultrasonic transducer.

2. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises providing the ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit and the cordless, rotatably free ultrasonic transducer within a shell of an ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly to expose a proximal end of the ultrasonic transducer to the environment for rotation by a user.

3. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises removably inserting at least a portion of a battery at an aseptically sealable battery-holding compartment of the ultrasonic surgical handle body.

4. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises removably inserting a battery into a selectively accessible and aseptically sealable battery-holding compartment of the ultrasonic surgical handle body.
5. The method according to claim 2, which further comprises retaining a battery at an aseptically sealed battery-holding compartment of one of the shell and the ultrasonic surgical handle body.

6. The method according to claim 2, which further comprises removably inserting a battery in an aseptically sealed battery-holding compartment of one of the shell and the ultrasonic surgical handle body.

7. The method according to claim 2, wherein:
the ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit and the cordless, rotatably free ultrasonic transducer are part of the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly;
the ultrasonic surgical handle body has a grip portion; and
an aseptically sealable battery-holding compartment is at one of the grip portion and the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly.

8. The method according to claim 1, wherein:
the ultrasonic transducer has an exposed proximal end;
the ultrasonic waveguide has an ultrasonic end effector; and
which further comprises touchlessly rotating the ultrasonic end effector by rotating the exposed proximal end of the ultrasonic transducer.

9. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises uncoupling the ultrasonic waveguide from the ultrasonic-movement-producing distal end of the ultrasonic transducer by rotating the ultrasonic waveguide with respect to the ultrasonic transducer.

10. The method according to claim 1, wherein the ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit is operable to generate an output waveform capable of causing ultrasonic movement in the ultrasonic waveguide through the ultrasonic transducer.
12. The method according to claim 11, further comprising removably inserting a battery at an aseptically sealable battery-holding compartment.

13. The method according to claim 12, wherein:
the handle body has a grip portion; and
the battery-holding compartment is disposed at one of:
the grip portion of the handle body; and
the ultrasonic-signal-generator assembly.
14. The method according to claim 11, further comprising manipulating an end effector of the ultrasonic waveguide by rotating the proximal end of the ultrasonic transducer.

15. The method according to claim 11, further comprising uncoupling the ultrasonic waveguide from the ultrasonic-movement-producing distal end of the ultrasonic transducer by rotating one of the ultrasonic waveguide and the ultrasonic transducer with respect to the other.

16. The method according to claim 11, wherein the ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit is operable to generate an output waveform capable of causing ultrasonic movement in the ultrasonic waveguide through the ultrasonic transducer.

17. The method according to claim 11, wherein the ultrasonic-signal-generator assembly further comprises a shell:
housing the ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit therein; and
housing at least a portion of the ultrasonic transducer therein such that the proximal end of the ultrasonic transducer is left exposed to the environment for rotation by the user.
18. The method according to claim 11, further comprising removably connecting a battery at a selectively accessible and aseptically sealable battery-holding compartment of the handle body.

title: Battery-Powered Hand-Held Ultrasonic Surgical Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: A battery assembly for use with a surgical device having a battery terminal and operational parameters includes a housing having a shape formed to removably connect with the terminal. The housing contains a modular battery operable to supply power to the device at the terminal and has a control circuit with a microprocessor, a memory, and a real-time clock. The control circuit is communicatively coupled to the battery and is operable to detect an identity of the surgical device, to determine at least one piece of information pertaining to at least one of the operational parameters of the surgical device based upon the detected identity, to record the piece of information at least in the memory, and to selectively allow or prevent the battery from supplying power to the surgical device dependent upon the piece of information.
claims:
2. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the surgical device comprises:
an ultrasonic waveguide;
a cordless ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly having:
an output couple operable to impart ultrasonic movement to the ultrasonic waveguide when the waveguide is connected thereto; and
a securing connector; and
a surgical handle having:
the battery terminal;
a waveguide attachment dock rotatably coupling the ultrasonic waveguide thereto; and
an ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly dock being operable, when the securing connector of the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly is removably secured at the surgical handle:
to electrically connect the battery assembly to the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly; and
to physically connect the ultrasonic waveguide to the output couple of the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly.

3. The battery assembly according to claim 2, wherein the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly comprises:
a driving-wave generation circuit having a generator output; and
a transducer communicatively coupled to the generator output.
4. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the at least one piece of information is an actual use count of at least one portion of the surgical device.
5. The battery assembly according to claim 4, wherein the control circuit is operable to record a total number of actual uses of the at least one portion of the surgical device.

6. The battery assembly according to claim 5, wherein the control circuit is operable to prevent the at least one modular battery from supplying power to the surgical device when the recorded total number of actual uses is at least a pre-defined maximum number of actual uses.

7. The battery assembly according to claim 4, wherein the control circuit is operable to determine the actual use count by:
determining a length of time that has elapsed since the last of the actual uses of the at least one portion with the real-time clock; and
if the determined length of time exceeds a pre-defined threshold, incrementing the recorded total number of actual uses of the at least one portion contained in the memory.

8. The battery assembly according to claim 5, wherein:
the at least one piece of information is a momentary lapse in use of at least a portion of the surgical device; and
the control circuit is operable to determine the momentary lapse in use by:
detecting a length of time that has elapsed since the last actual use of the at least one portion; and
if the detected length of time is less than a pre-defined threshold, determining that a momentary lapse in use of the at least one portion has occurred.

9. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the control circuit is operable to determine if either of an actual use and a momentary lapse in use of the surgical device has occurred by:
detecting a length of time that has elapsed since a last use of the surgical device;
if the detected length of time meets or exceeds a pre-defined threshold, determining that an actual use has occurred; and
if the detected length of time is less than the pre-defined threshold, determining that a momentary lapse in use has occurred.
10. The battery assembly according to claim 9, wherein the control circuit is operable to record a total number of actual uses of the surgical device.

11. The battery assembly according to claim 10, wherein the control circuit is operable to prevent the at least one modular battery from supplying power to the surgical device when the recorded total number of actual uses meets or exceeds a pre-defined maximum number of actual uses.

12. The battery assembly according to claim 1, further comprising the surgical device comprising:
an ultrasonic waveguide having a proximal end for receiving ultrasonic movement thereat;
a cordless ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly having:
a driving-wave generation circuit having a generator output; and
a transducer communicatively coupled to the generator output and having an ultrasonic-movement-producing end operable to removably connect to the proximal end of the ultrasonic waveguide; and
a surgical handle having:
the battery terminal;
a waveguide attachment dock rotatably coupling the ultrasonic waveguide thereto; and
an ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly dock being operable, when the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly is removably secured at the surgical handle:
to electrically connect the battery assembly to the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly; and
to physically connect the ultrasonic waveguide to the ultrasonic-movement-producing end of the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly.
13. The battery assembly according to claim 12, wherein the at least one piece of information is an actual use count of at least one portion of the surgical device.
14. The battery assembly according to claim 13, wherein the control circuit is operable to record a total number of actual uses of the at least one portion of the surgical device.

15. The battery assembly according to claim 14, wherein the control circuit is operable to prevent the at least one modular battery from supplying power to the surgical device when the recorded total number of actual uses is at least a pre-defined maximum number of actual uses.

16. The battery assembly according to claim 14, wherein the control circuit is operable to determine the actual use count by:
determining a length of time that has elapsed since the last of the actual uses of the at least one portion with the real-time clock; and
if the determined length of time exceeds a pre-defined threshold, incrementing the recorded total number of actual uses of the at least one portion contained in the memory.

17. The battery assembly according to claim 12, wherein:
the at least one piece of information is a momentary lapse in use of at least one portion of the surgical device; and
the control circuit is operable to determine a momentary lapse in use by:
detecting a length of time that has elapsed since the last actual use of the at least one portion; and
if the detected length of time is less than a pre-defined threshold, determining that a momentary lapse in use of the at least one portion has occurred.

18. The battery assembly according to claim 12, wherein the control circuit is operable to determine if either of an actual use and a momentary lapse in use of the surgical device has occurred by:
detecting a length of time that has elapsed since a last use of the surgical device;
if the detected length of time meets or exceeds a pre-defined threshold, determining that an actual use has occurred; and
if the detected length of time is less than the pre-defined threshold, determining that a momentary lapse in use has occurred.
19. The battery assembly according to claim 18, wherein the control circuit is operable to record a total number of actual use of the surgical device.

20. The battery assembly according to claim 19, wherein the control circuit is operable to prevent the at least one modular battery from supplying power to the surgical device when the recorded total number of actual uses meets or exceeds a pre-defined maximum number of actual uses.

title: Battery Assembly for Battery-Powered Surgical Instruments
abstract: A battery assembly is used in battery-powered surgical instruments with handles having a battery chamber and different handle types. The battery assembly includes a housing having an exterior shape formed to removably connect with the battery chamber of the handles and a voltage-control circuit. The housing has at least one energy storage cell operable to power a signal generation assembly of the surgical instruments and a battery/handle interface having a plurality of connectors shaped to mate with a plurality of corresponding connectors within the battery chamber of the handles. The voltage-control circuit is operable to communicatively couple with and provide power to the signal generation assembly, detect which one of the handle types is connected to the housing, provide a first output in response to a detection of a first handle type, and provide at least a second output in response to a detection of a second handle type.
claims:
1. A battery assembly for use in a number of battery-powered surgical instruments with handles having a battery chamber and different handle types, the battery assembly comprising:
a housing having an exterior shape formed to removably connect with the battery chamber of the handles, the housing having:
at least one energy storage cell operable to power a signal generation assembly of the surgical instruments; and
a battery/handle interface having a plurality of connectors shaped to mate with a plurality of corresponding connectors within the battery chamber of the handles; and
a voltage-control circuit operable to:
communicatively couple with and provide power to the signal generation assembly;
detect which one of the handle types is connected to the housing;
provide a first output in response to a detection of a first handle type; and
provide at least a second output in response to a detection of at least a second handle type.

2. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein:
the battery-powered surgical instrument is a cordless, hand-held, ultrasonic cautery cutting device; and
the signal generation assembly comprises an ultrasonic-signal-generation assembly.

3. The battery assembly according to claim 2, wherein:
the first output is an ultrasonic-signal-generation assembly output signal for a first type of ultrasonic waveguide; and
the second output is an ultrasonic-signal-generation assembly output signal for a second type of ultrasonic waveguide different from the first type of ultrasonic waveguide.

4. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the voltage-control circuit comprises a memory operable to receive and store at least one piece of information pertaining to the surgical instrument handle.

5. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the voltage-control circuit comprises:
a memory operable to receive and store at least one piece of information; and
a communication interface coupled to the memory and operable to communicate information from the memory to an information receiver remote from the battery assembly.

7. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the voltage-control circuit comprises a memory operable to store at least two output voltage profiles, each profile corresponding to one of a surgical instrument handle type and a surgical instrument attachment.

8. The battery assembly according to claim 7, wherein the voltage-control circuit comprises:
a processor communicatively coupled to the memory and operable to:
interrogate the surgical instrument handle for at least one piece of information pertaining to the surgical instrument handle;
receive an instruction from the memory corresponding to the at least one piece of information pertaining to the surgical instrument handle; and
drive the voltage-control circuit according to the instruction.
9. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the battery assembly is at least one of watertightly sealed and autoclavably sealed.

10. The battery assembly according to claim 2, further comprising:
a surgical cautery and cutting end effector assembly; and
a handle being at least one of the first and second handle types and attached to the surgical cautery and cutting end effector assembly.

11. The battery assembly according to claim 10, wherein the surgical cautery and cutting end effector assembly comprises:
at least one jaw member; and
a cutting blade disposed adjacent the at least one jaw member.

12. The battery assembly according to claim 11, wherein the surgical cautery and cutting end effector assembly comprises:
an ultrasonic waveguide; and
the cutting blade is a part of the ultrasonic waveguide.

13. In combination with a battery-powered surgical instrument having:
a signal generation assembly;
different handle types with the handles each having a battery chamber, the signal generation assembly connected to the handle; and
the battery chamber having connectors therewithin electrically connected to the signal generation assembly,
the improvement comprising:
a battery assembly having:
a housing having an exterior shape formed to removably connect with the battery chamber of the handles, the housing having:
at least one energy storage cell operable to power the signal generation assembly of the surgical instruments; and
a battery/handle interface having a plurality of connectors shaped to mate with the connectors within each battery chamber; and
a voltage-control circuit operable to:
communicatively couple with and provide power to the signal generation assembly;
detect which one of the handle types is connected to the housing;
provide a first output in response to a detection of a first handle type; and
provide at least a second output in response to a detection of at least a second handle type.

14. The battery assembly according to claim 13, wherein:
the battery-powered surgical instrument is a cordless, hand-held, ultrasonic cautery cutting device; and
the signal generation assembly comprises an ultrasonic-signal-generation assembly.

15. The battery assembly according to claim 2, wherein:
the first output is an ultrasonic-signal-generation assembly output signal for a first type of ultrasonic waveguide; and
the second output is an ultrasonic-signal-generation assembly output signal for a second type of ultrasonic waveguide different from the first type of ultrasonic waveguide.

17. The battery assembly according to claim 16, wherein the voltage-control circuit comprises:
a processor communicatively coupled to the memory and operable to:
interrogate the surgical instrument handle for at least one piece of information pertaining to the surgical instrument handle;
receive an instruction from the memory corresponding to the at least one piece of information pertaining to the surgical instrument handle; and
drive the voltage-control circuit according to the instruction.
18. The battery assembly according to claim 1, wherein the battery assembly is at least one of watertightly sealed and autoclavably sealed.

19. A cordless, hand-held, ultrasonic cautery cutting device, comprising:
an ultrasonic signal generation assembly;
at least one handle selected from a set of different handle types each having a battery chamber, the battery chamber having connectors therewithin and electrically connected to the ultrasonic signal generation assembly; and
a removable battery assembly having:
a housing with an exterior shape formed to removably connect with the battery chamber of each of the handles, the housing having:
at least one energy storage cell operable to power the ultrasonic signal generation assembly; and
a battery/handle interface having a plurality of connectors shaped to mate with the connectors within the battery chamber; and
a voltage-control circuit operable to:
communicatively couple with and provide power to the ultrasonic signal generation assembly;
detect which one of the handle types is connected to the housing;
provide a first output in response to a detection of a first handle type; and
provide at least a second output in response to a detection of at least a second handle type.

21. The cordless, hand-held, ultrasonic cautery cutting device according to claim 20, wherein the voltage-control circuit comprises:

receive an instruction from the memory corresponding to the at least one piece of information pertaining to the surgical instrument handle; and
drive the voltage-control circuit according to the instruction.
22. The cordless, hand-held, ultrasonic cautery cutting device according to claim 19, wherein the battery assembly is at least one of watertightly sealed and autoclavably sealed.

title: Method of Switching a Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: A method for operating an ultrasonic, self-powered surgical device, includes the steps of connecting a self-contained power supply to a surgical device handle, providing a control circuit within at least one of the handle and the power supply, the control circuit being operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device, and effecting the at least two operational conditions with a two-stage switch electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition.
claims:
1. A method for operating an ultrasonic, self-powered surgical device, comprising:
connecting a self-contained power supply to a surgical device handle;
providing a control circuit within at least one of the handle and the power supply, the control circuit being operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and
effecting the at least two operational conditions with a two-stage switch electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition.
2. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises controlling an amount of power delivered from the power supply with the control circuit.

3. The method according to claim 2, wherein the first operational condition is a first amount of power delivered from the power supply and the second operational condition is a second amount of power delivered from the power supply.

4. The method according to claim 2, which further comprises delivering a first amount of power from the power supply in the first operational condition and delivering a second amount of power different from the first amount from the power supply in the second operational condition.
5. The method according to claim 4, wherein the first amount of power is less than the second amount.

6. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises:
effecting the first and second operational conditions using at least one electrical contact of the two-stage switch to electrically close the control circuit.

7. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises:
effecting the first and second operational conditions using at least one electrical contact of the two-stage switch to electrically break the control circuit.

8. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises:
switching between the first and second stages by changing a position of the two-stage switch.
9. The method according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch is in the first stage when in a first position.
10. The method according to claim 9, wherein the two-stage switch is in the second stage when in a second position.
11. The method according to claim 10, wherein the first and second positions are operably connected in a stacked configuration.

12. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises:
switching to the first stage by partially depressing the two-stage switch.

13. The method according to claim 12, which further comprises:
switching to the second stage by fully depressing the two-stage switch.

14. The method according to claim 8, which further comprises:
coupling a plunger to the two-stage switch; and
changing the position of the two-stage switch by applying pressure to the plunger.
15. The method according to claim 14, wherein the plunger is spring-biased.

16. The method according to claim 14, which further comprises:
applying a variable amount of pressure to the plunger to cause the two-stage switch to change position.

17. The method according to claim 16, wherein an amount of pressure needed to position the two-stage switch in the first stage is less than the amount of pressure needed to position the two-stage switch in the second stage.

18. The method according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch is comprised of at least a first sub-switch and a second sub-switch, the first sub-switch effecting the first operational condition and the second sub-switch effecting the second operational condition.

title: Method of maintaining constant movement of a cutting blade on an ultrasonic waveguide
abstract: A method of maintaining a constant movement of a cutting blade of an ultrasonic waveguide includes providing an ultrasonic transducer operable to convert a received motional current into a movement of a cutting blade of an ultrasonic waveguide, a measurement circuit connected in a parallel configuration with the ultrasonic transducer, and a variable power source operable to supply current through a set of connection points to the parallel configuration and thereby create the motional current in the ultrasonic transducer. Current is supplied through a set of connection points of the parallel configuration with the variable power source to, thereby, create the motional current in the ultrasonic transducer and the motional current is regulated with a current controller by varying an output of the power source, thereby maintaining a substantially constant rate of movement of the cutting blade across a variety of cutting loads.
claims:
2. The method according to claim 1, wherein:
the current controller comprises a processor; and
the variable power source comprises a phase locked loop communicatively coupled to the processor, and which further comprises:
determining a frequency of movement of the cutting blade with the phase locked loop; and
storing a last frequency of blade movement in a memory communicatively coupled to the processor.
3. The method according to claim 1, wherein the variable power source comprises a removable battery.

5. A method of maintaining a constant movement of a cutting blade of an ultrasonic waveguide, which comprises:
providing:
an ultrasonic transducer operable to convert a received motional current into a movement of a cutting blade of an ultrasonic waveguide, the ultrasonic transducer having a first capacitance in a parallel configuration with a series configuration of a resistance, an inductance and a second capacitance, whereby the motional current flows through the series configuration; and
a third capacitance in a parallel configuration with the first capacitance;
supplying current through a set of connection points of the parallel configuration with a variable power source coupled to the third capacitance and the ultrasonic transducer to, thereby, create the motional current in the ultrasonic transducer; and
regulating the motional current with a current controller by varying an output of the power source based upon a product of the current flowing through the third capacitance multiplied by a ratio between a value of the first capacitance and a value of the third capacitance subtracted from a total current flowing into the ultrasonic transducer, thereby maintaining a substantially constant rate of movement of the cutting blade across a variety of cutting loads.

6. The method according to claim 5, wherein:
the current controller comprises a processor; and
the variable power source comprises a phase locked loop communicatively coupled to the processor, and which further comprises:
determining a frequency of movement of the cutting blade with the phase locked loop; and
storing a last frequency of blade movement in a memory communicatively coupled to the processor.

7. The method according to claim 5, which further comprises:
providing a clamping mechanism having a range of clamping force values and being operable to place material in physical contact with the cutting blade;
communicatively coupling the current controller to the clamping mechanism; and
varying the motional current with the current controller based upon a given clamping value within the range of clamping values.
8. The method according to claim 5, wherein the variable power source comprises a removable battery.

11. The method according to claim 10, wherein:
the current controller comprises a processor; and
the variable power source comprises a phase locked loop communicatively coupled to the processor, and which further comprises:
determining a frequency of movement of the cutting blade with the phase locked loop; and
storing a last frequency of blade movement in a memory communicatively coupled to the processor.

12. The method according to claim 10, which further comprises:
providing a clamping mechanism having a range of clamping force values and being operable to place material in physical contact with the cutting blade;
communicatively coupling the current controller to the clamping mechanism; and
varying the motional current with the current controller based upon a given clamping value within the range of clamping values.
14. The method according to claim 13, wherein the variable power source comprises a removable battery.

title: Cordless hand-held ultrasonic cautery cutting device
abstract: An ultrasonic surgical assembly connectable to an ultrasonic surgical handle having an ultrasonic waveguide, the assembly comprising: an exterior body defining an internal compartment and having a connection operable to removably secure the body in a body-holding compartment within the ultrasonic surgical handle; a cordless ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly disposed in the internal compartment and having an output couple removably attachable to the ultrasonic waveguide and operable to impart ultrasonic movement to the ultrasonic waveguide; and a battery disposed in the internal compartment and electrically connected to and powering the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly.

title: Method of switching a surgical device
abstract: Method for operating a surgical device, comprising providing a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device and effecting the at least two operational conditions with a two-stage switch electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition, wherein the force required to sustain the first operational condition is less than the force required to enter the first operational condition and the force required to enter the second operational condition is greater than the force required to sustain the first operational condition.
claims:
1. A method for operating a surgical device, comprising:
providing a control circuit operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device; and
effecting the at least two operational conditions with a two-stage switch electrically connected to the control circuit, a first stage of the switch effecting a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effecting a second of the at least two operational conditions different from the first operational condition, wherein the force required to sustain the first operational condition is less than the force required to enter the first operational condition and the force required to enter the second operational condition is greater than the force required to sustain the first operational condition.

2. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises:
providing a handle of the surgical device with a self-contained power supply; and
controlling an amount of power delivered from the power supply with the control circuit.

3. The method according to claim 2, wherein the first operational condition is a first amount of power delivered from the power supply and the second operational condition is a second amount of power delivered from the power supply.

4. The method according to claim 2, which further comprises delivering a first amount of power from the power supply in the first operational condition and delivering a second amount of power different from the first amount from the power supply in the second operational condition.
5. The method according to claim 4, wherein the first amount of power is less than the second amount.

6. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises effecting the first and second operational conditions using at least one electrical contact of the two-stage switch to electrically close the control circuit.

7. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises effecting the first and second operational conditions using at least one electrical contact of the two-stage switch to electrically break the control circuit.
8. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises switching between the first and second stages by changing a position of the two-stage switch.
9. The method according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch is in the first stage when placed in a first position by applying the first depression force.
10. The method according to claim 9, wherein the two-stage switch is in the second stage when placed in a second position by applying the second depression force.
11. The method according to claim 10, wherein the first and second positions are operably connected in a stacked configuration.
12. The method according to claim 1, which further comprises switching to the first stage by applying the first depression force to partially depress the two-stage switch.
13. The method according to claim 12, which further comprises switching to the second stage by applying the second depression force to fully depress the two-stage switch.

14. The method according to claim 8, which further comprises:
coupling a plunger to the two-stage switch; and
changing the position of the two-stage switch by applying pressure to the plunger.

16. The method according to claim 14, which further comprises:
applying a variable amount of pressure to the plunger to cause the two-stage switch to change position.

18. The method according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch is comprised of at least a first sub-switch and a second sub-switch, the first sub-switch effecting the first stage and the second sub-switch effecting the second stage.

title: Two-Stage Switch for Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: An ultrasonic, self-powered surgical device includes a handle, a self-contained power supply associated with the handle, and a control circuit disposed within the handle and/or the power supply. The control circuit is operable to carry out at least two operational conditions of the surgical device. A two-stage switch is electrically connected to the control circuit and effects the at least two operational conditions of the surgical device. A first stage of the switch effects a first of the at least two operational conditions and a second stage of the switch effects a second of the at least two operational conditions that is different from the first operational condition.
claims: 2. The device according to claim 1, wherein the control circuit is operable to control the amount of power delivered from the power supply.

6. The device according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch has first and second positions and is operable to switch between the first and second stages by changing between the first and second positions.
7. The device according to claim 6, wherein the two-stage switch is in the first stage when in the first position.

14. The device according to claim 12, wherein a variable amount of pressure is applied to the plunger to cause the two-stage switch to change position.

15. The device according to claim 12, wherein the amount of pressure needed to position the two-stage switch in the first stage is less than the amount of pressure needed to position the two-stage switch in the second stage.

16. The device according to claim 1, wherein the two-stage switch is comprised of at least a first sub-switch and a second sub-switch, the first sub-switch effecting the first operational condition and the second sub-switch effecting the second operational condition.

18. The device according to claim 17, wherein:
the two-stage switch is in the first stage when in the first position; and
the two-stage switch is in the second stage when in the second position.

title: Method of powering a surgical instrument
abstract: A method for powering electrically powered surgical instruments includes removably inserting a cordless battery assembly into a handle thereof, the instrument handles having a battery chamber and different types. The battery assembly comprises an energy cell powering a signal generation assembly of the instruments. A battery/handle interface has connectors mating with connectors within the chamber. A voltage-control circuit is operable to communicate with and power the signal generation assembly, detect which handle type is connected to the battery assembly, and provide different outputs in response to a detection of the handle types. As the battery assembly is inserted, connectors of the battery/handle interface are coupled with connectors within the battery chamber to communicatively couple the voltage-control circuit to the signal generation assembly and provide power thereto. The connected handle is detected and dependent upon the detected handle type a different one of the outputs are provided.
claims:
2. The method according to claim 1, wherein

title: Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: A disposable ultrasonic surgical handle connectable to an ultrasonic waveguide, a battery, and an ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly includes a first handle body portion defining therein an aseptically sealable battery-holding compartment shaped to receive the battery therein, a second handle body portion connected to the first handle body portion, and an electrical couple. The second handle body portion has a waveguide attachment dock exposed to the environment and an ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly dock exposed to the environment and shaped to connect the ultrasonic waveguide in the waveguide attachment dock to the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly through the second handle body portion. The electrical couple is operable to connect a battery within the battery-holding compartment to the ultrasonic-movement-generator-assembly when the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly is docked at the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly dock.
claims:
1. A disposable ultrasonic surgical handle connectable to an ultrasonic waveguide, a battery, and an ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly, the handle comprising:

a waveguide attachment dock exposed to the environment; and
an ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly dock exposed to the environment and shaped to connect the ultrasonic waveguide in the waveguide attachment dock to the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly through the second handle body portion; and
an electrical couple operable to connect the battery within the battery-holding compartment to the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly when the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly is docked at the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly dock.
2. The handle according to claim 1, wherein the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly dock is one of a rail, a dovetail, a T-slot, and an undercut slot.
3. The handle according to claim 1, wherein the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly is an ultrasonic transducer-and-generator assembly.
4. The handle according to claim 1, wherein the electrical couple comprises conductive power leads disposed in the battery-holding compartment and positioned to electrically contact the battery.

5. The handle according to claim 1, wherein at least one of the waveguide attachment dock and the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly dock rotatably couples at least one of the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly and the waveguide to the second handle body portion.

6. The handle according to claim 5, wherein:

7. The handle according to claim 1, further comprising a compartment door movably attached to the first handle body portion and having:
an open position permitting entry and removal of the battery respectively into and out from the compartment; and
a closed position aseptically sealing the compartment from the environment.
8. The handle according to claim 1 wherein the first handle body portion is a handgrip.
9. The handle according to claim 8, wherein the battery-holding compartment is disposed in a lower portion of the handgrip.
10. The handle according to claim 1, further comprising a memory for storing a handle use history.

11. The handle according to claim 1, further comprising a device identifier communicatively coupled to the battery-holding compartment and operable to communicate at least one piece of information about at least one of the handle, the waveguide, the battery, and the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly.
12. The handle according to claim 11, wherein the at least one piece of information is at least one of a handle identifier, an information list of previous use, and a waveguide identifier.

13. The handle according to claim 11, further comprising a removable battery assembly, the device identifier being operable to communicate with the battery assembly and to transfer information therebetween.

15. The handle according to claim 1, wherein the first and second handle body portions are integral.
16. The handle according to claim 1, further comprising conductive power leads in the compartment and positioned to electrically contact the battery when the battery is in the compartment.

17. The handle according to claim 1, further comprising an ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly having:
a driving-wave generation circuit generating an output waveform; and
a transducer having an output couple shaped to connect to the ultrasonic waveguide and being communicatively coupled to the driving-wave generation circuit to create ultrasonic movement at the output couple to ultrasonically move the waveguide when attached thereto.

18. The handle according to claim 17, wherein the driving-wave generation circuit comprises at least one of:

a drive circuit; and
a matching circuit.

title: Cordless hand-held ultrasonic cautery cutting device
abstract: PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide an ultrasonic assembly detachably connectable to an ultrasonic waveguide of an ultrasonic surgical handle.SOLUTION: An ultrasonic surgery device 1300 comprises: a cordless ultrasonic movement generation assembly which has an ultrasonic generator and an ultrasonic transducer 1302 electrically connected to the generator and having an output couple; and a shell which includes the ultrasonic movement generation assembly, and has a fixing connection part formed to be detachably connected to the ultrasonic surgical handle 1408. When the fixing connection part is connected to the ultrasonic surgical handle and the waveguide 1310 is connected to the output couple, the output couple is operable to transmit ultrasonic movement to the ultrasonic waveguide.

title: Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: An ultrasonic surgical assembly includes an ultrasonic waveguide and a cordless ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly that has a selectively removable securing connector and an output couple operable to impart ultrasonic movement to the ultrasonic waveguide when the waveguide is connected thereto. The assembly also includes a removable battery and a surgical handle that has a first handle body portion defining therein an aseptically sealable battery-holding compartment selectively exposed to the environment, aseptically removably holding therein the battery and electrically connecting the battery therein to the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly. A second handle body portion is connected to the first handle body portion and has a waveguide attachment dock that is exposed to the environment and has a first couple operable to connect the waveguide thereto and an ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly dock that is exposed to the environment and shaped to removably secure the second handle body portion to the securing connector and connect the ultrasonic waveguide in the attachment dock to the output couple through the second handle body portion.
claims:

a surgical handle having:

selectively exposed to the environment;

title: Two -stage switch for cordless hand-held ultrasonic cautery cutting device

title: Battery powered hand-held ultrasonic surgical cautery cutting device
abstract: BATTERY-POWERED HAND-HELD ULTRASONIC SURGICAL CAUTERY CUTTING DEVICE A battery-powered, modular surgical device includes an electrically powered surgical instrument operable to surgically interface with human tissue and a handle assembly (302) connected to the surgical instrument. The handle assembly (302) has a removable hand grip and a handle body (3500). The hand grip is shaped to permit handling of the surgical device by one hand of an operator, has an upper portion and a cordless internal battery assembly (301) that powers the surgical instrument. The internal battery assembly (301) has at least one energy storage cell. The handle body (3500) is operable to removably connect at least the upper portion of the hand grip thereto and create an aseptic seal around at least a portion of the hand grip when connected thereto and electrically couple the internal battery assembly (301) of the hand grip to the surgical instrument and thereby power the surgical instrument for interfacing surgically with the human tissue. title: Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device

electrically connecting the removable battery disposed thereat to the ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit when the selectively removable securing connector of the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly is connected to the first handle body portion.

24. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 23, wherein the assembly dock is operable to substantially simultaneously:
axially align the ultrasonic-movement-producing distal end of the ultrasonic transducer opposite the proximal end of the ultrasonic waveguide when the ultrasonic waveguide is disposed within the waveguide attachment dock;
removably secure the securing connector of the ultrasonic-movement-generator assembly to the first handle body portion; and
electrically couple the ultrasonic-driving-wave-signal generating circuit to the removable battery.

25. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 23, wherein:

the waveguide attachment dock is operable to rotatably couple the ultrasonic waveguide in the waveguide attachment dock to the ultrasonic transducer in the assembly dock through the first handle body portion.

title: Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: An ultrasonic surgical assembly includes an ultrasonic transducer operable to convert a received motional current into a movement of a cutting blade of an ultrasonic waveguide, a measurement circuit connected in a parallel configuration with the ultrasonic transducer, a variable power source operable to supply current through a set of connection points to the parallel configuration and thereby create the motional current in the ultrasonic transducer, and a current controller operable to regulate the motional current by varying an output of the variable power source, thereby maintaining a substantially constant rate of movement of the cutting blade across a variety of cutting loads.
claims:

title: Cordless Hand-Held Ultrasonic Cautery Cutting Device
abstract: An ultrasonic surgical assembly for connection to an ultrasonic surgical handle includes a reusable exterior body defining an internal compartment and having a connection operable to removably secure the body in a body-holding compartment within the ultrasonic surgical handle, a reusable cordless ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly disposed in the compartment and having an output couple removably attachable to an ultrasonic waveguide and operable to impart ultrasonic movement to the ultrasonic waveguide, and a reusable and rechargeable battery disposed in the compartment and electrically connected to and powering the assembly.
claims:
1. An ultrasonic surgical assembly connectable to an ultrasonic surgical handle having an ultrasonic waveguide, the assembly comprising:
an exterior body defining an internal compartment and having a connection operable to removably secure the body in a body-holding compartment within the ultrasonic surgical handle;
a cordless ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly disposed in the internal compartment and having an output couple removably attachable to the ultrasonic waveguide and operable to impart ultrasonic movement to the ultrasonic waveguide; and
a battery disposed in the internal compartment and electrically connected to and powering the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly.

2. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 1, wherein the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly comprises:
a driving-wave generation circuit electrically coupled to the battery and having a generator output; and
an ultrasonic transducer communicatively coupled to the generator output.

3. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 2, wherein the driving-wave generation circuit comprises at least one of:
a control circuit;
a drive circuit; and
a matching circuit.
4. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 2, wherein the transducer is rotatable with respect to at least one of the body and the driving-wave generation circuit.

5. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 2, further comprising:
a reusable compartment door movably connected to the body to selectively expose the compartment to the environment and having:
an open position permitting entry and removal of at least one of the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly and the battery respectively into and out from the compartment; and
a closed position sealing the compartment from the environment.
6. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 5, wherein the closed position at least one of water-tightly and aseptically seals the compartment from the environment.
7. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 6, wherein the battery is interchangeably disposed in the body.
8. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 1, wherein the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly is powered only by the battery.

9. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 1, wherein the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly is operable to vary at least one of a driving-wave frequency and a driving-wave power based on an identified type of the waveguide.
10. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 1, wherein the output couple extends out of the body from the ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly.
11. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 1, wherein the battery is interchangeably disposed in the body.

12. The ultrasonic surgical assembly according to claim 1, wherein:
at least one of the exterior body and the cordless ultrasonic-movement-generation assembly is reusable.

title: Battery-powered hand-held ultrasonic surgical cautery cutting device
abstract: A battery assembly (301) for use with a surgical device (300) having a battery terminal and operational parameters includes a housing having a shape formed to removably connect with the terminal. The housing contains a modular battery operable to supply power to the device at the terminal and has a control circuit with a microprocessor, a memory, and a real-time clock. The control circuit is communicatively coupled to the battery and is operable to detect an identity of the surgical device (300), to determine at least one piece of information pertaining to at least one of the operational parameters of the surgical device (300) based upon the detected identity, to record the piece of information at least in the memory, and to selectively allow or prevent the battery from supplying power to the surgical device (300) dependent upon the piece of information.

title: Cordless hand-held ultrasonic cautery cutting device
abstract: PROBLEM TO BE SOLVED: To provide a cordless hand-held ultrasonic surgical cutting device of a completely electric drive control type.SOLUTION: An ultrasonic assembly detachably connectable to an ultrasonic waveguide 1310 of an ultrasonic surgical handle 1408 comprises: a cordless ultrasonic movement generation assembly which has an ultrasonic generator and an ultrasonic transducer 1302 electrically connected to the generator and having an output couple; and a shell which includes the ultrasonic movement generation assembly, and has a fixing connection part formed to be detachably connected to the ultrasonic surgical handle. When the fixing connection part is connected to the ultrasonic surgical handle and the waveguide is connected to the output couple, the output couple is operable to transmit ultrasonic movement to the ultrasonic waveguide.
